results.title: Preserving native grasslands
results.creator_credit: Conservation Forrest and Lands and Victoria. Dept of Conservation, Forests and Lands
results.brief_description: This program examines the problem of our disappearing native grasslands due to the urban sprawl, introduced species and weeds. The department of Conservation, Forests and Land have put out a booklet promoting public awareness of native plants (grasses, flowers and herbs), when and how to identify them, and the various steps involved in preserving them. No other credits available.

results.title: Planning a tree planting program
results.creator_credit: Gerry North and Western Australia. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Advises farmers on the necessary steps to take in planning a tree planting program, including identifying problem areas that trees can help rectify, choosing appropriate varieties and budgeting.

results.title: One billion trees: towards the greening of Australia
results.brief_description: Examines the subject of tree conservation in Australia. In the past with European settlement, trees were demolished at a rapid rate to make room for livestock and agriculture, our early settlers were unaware that only 15% of Australia was covered by trees. With our policy of deliberate tree felling that percentage has dropped to 5, and the delicate balance of the ecosystems have been distrubed leading to soil erosion and a loss of agricultural productivity. A national tree program titled “Greening Australia” is going on in many parts of the country promoting public awareness and community action. Greening Australia is helping the community grow 1 billion tree by the year 2000. No other credits available.

results.title: Achievements in salinity control
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Rural Affairs
results.brief_description: Looks at the problem of salinity and its effects on irrigated agriculture. Explains the formation of the water table and the resultant salinity due to poor drainage and evaporation. Focuses on a number of strategies and research developments to combat the problem.

results.title: Mixing solutions
results.brief_description: Looks at safety measures to adopt when mixing chemical herbicides in a farming situation. Gives sound advice in an easily followed format.

results.title: Soil: more than dirt
results.brief_description: This program lokks at land degredation due to salting, soil erosion and soil structure decline because of over use of the land itself, this in turn leads to low agricultural productivity. The research done by the department of Conservation, Forests and Land suggests ways and means of better land management practices. No other credits

results.title: The Big Dry
results.brief_description: The 1982-83 drought in North- west Victoria and South Australia impacted heavily on the environment. This tape examines the effect of the drought in the Mallee region in terms of soil conservation. This area experienced severe soil erosion as farmers were forced to overgraze livestock, in particular sheep.

results.title: Water erosion and waterlogging
results.creator_credit: Gerry North and Western Australia. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Water erosion can result in the complete degradation of land by the removal of topsoils to expose infertile clay subsoils. The adoption of minimum tillage and other farm management techniques can lessen the risk of water erosion and improve farm productivity.

results.title: Future looks rosy
results.brief_description: Looks at the problems of soil salinity due to erosion and poor agricultural practices. In cooperation with the Department of Conservation, Forests & Land, landholders are seeking solutions to the problem of land degradation.

results.title: The weeping earth: salt in South Eastern Australia
results.brief_description: Dr Jim Bowler introduces a program addressing the scourge of the Australian land - salt - a side effect of settlement and clearing. Discusses the situation before European settlement and examines why salt is such a problem by looking at the history of the Australian landscape.
